Consider $A=\{p,2p,\dots,(q-1)p\}$ and $B=\{q,2q,\dots,(p-1)q\}$. It's easy to see that $A\cap B=\emptyset$, because assuming for some $0<i<q$, $0<j<p$ we have $ip=jq$, this implies that $q|i$ and $p|j$, impossible. Also, since all their elements are less than $pq$, we have $(A\cup B)\in \{1,2,\dots,pq-1\}$. Hence we get $\prod_{k\in A\cup B}k|(pq-1)!$.\\
But since $A\cap B=\emptyset$, here $\prod_{k\in A\cup B}k=\prod_{k\in A}k\cdot \prod_{k\in B}k=p^{q-1}(q-1)!\cdot q^{p-1}(p-1)!$. QED.
